author: Sally Peck
title: How to celebrate the Fourth of July if you’re British
text: The Anglo-American "Special Relationship" is much celebrated, at least on this side of the pond. So if you find yourself in the Mother Country on Independence Day, when Americans worldwide celebrate their separation from Britain, here’s where to march, eat, boogie and drown your sorrows over the lost colonies. Partisan party Sunday 5 July 12-5 Each year Democrats Abroad (not that we’re taking sides) hosts a picnic for US citizens or permanent residents, and their families, in Portman Square. Oddly, it’s on the 5th of July. Where in America to celebrate the Fourth of July Independence Day BBQ (don’t call it a ‘cookout’) Friday 3 July, 5.30-8.30pm Rock out to the best of Fifties and Sixties tunes, or recline lazily on your picnic rug and enjoy a great outdoor evening of music, food, and family fun with cover band Kabinrock at the American Museum, Bath 'Spirit Hawk Eye' is a special exhibition at the American Museum in Britain of portraits by Heidi Laughton celebrating contemporary Native American culture Photo: Heidi Laughton While you are at the museum, check out the ‘Spirit Hawk Eye’, a special exhibition of portraits by photographer and Bath resident, Heidi Laughton, celebrating contemporary Native American culture. Three of the Native Americans photographed for project will visit the museum from July 16 to 23, leading special activities, including dance demonstrations and lessons in traditional painting and craft techniques. (See americanmuseum.org for further details.) 'Spirit Hawk Eye' is a special exhibition at the American Museum in Britain of portraits by Heidi Laughton celebrating contemporary Native American culture Photo: Heidi Laughton The exhibition is open until November 1, Tuesday – Sunday, noon-5pm, Closed Mondays except during August and Bank Holidays War of Independence Drills Saturday 4 and Sunday 5 July, 2-4 His Majesty’s Crown Forces offer a blast from the past, again at the American Museum in Bath, with their special blend of military prowess, scruffy recruits, good humour, and one incredibly loud cannon. This year, children can join in to see if they have what it takes to join the regiment. Drill Displays: 2pm & 3.45pm Kids’ Drill: 2.45pm Eat the part Balthazar, London WC2 Photo: MARK WHITFIELD You could do worse than going to Balthazar’s Fourth of July brunch. More a NYC institution than a straight French brasserie, you’ll find hot dogs with Comte here . If French dogs aren’t your bag, head to the Lockhart for fried chicken and cornbread, or the newly opened London branch of the US steakhouse Smith & Wollensky for an unseasonably rich meal. Good riddance Or, you could just go to the pub, shrug your shoulders, raise your pint and toast the Americans’ independence. American-style microbrews are massive at the moment.
